Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Object Pose Estimation System for Pick and Place Robots
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is improvement in cost-efficiency, energy-efficiency, and quality in manufacturing automation, increasing worker productivity and reducing repetitive motion injuries. This integrated visual-tactile system will be 3-4 times more inexpensive ($20,000 purchase cost vs. existing $65,000-80,000 vision system), improve the speed and accuracy of current robotic handling systems, and facilitate the automation of repetitive, injury-prone manual tasks. By enabling new robotic applications and increasing productivity in current automation, this solution will help the U.S. maintain a competitive domestic manufacturing sector. In 2009 there were 36,190 logged repetitive motion injuries in the U.S.; the median missed work time from these injuries was 21 days (U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics). This innovative solution will facilitate the automation of repetitive, injury-prone manual tasks and greatly improve the speed, accuracy, and cost-efficiency of current robotic handling systems. The immediate commercial applications are in industrial robotics, specifically robotics in agile manufacturing. In the long term, the technology will be applied in personal, healthcare, and military robots. The current market potential for tactile sensors for industrial robots is estimated as $576 million - $1.15 billion and expected to more than double by 2025.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase 2 project will result in a combined visual-tactile system that will give robots an integrated sense of touch and vision, much like the hand-eye coordination of humans. It incorporates a technically novel compliant tactile sensing solution?a rubber ?skin? that can be molded into any form factor and is inexpensive and durable. This advanced skin technology can resolve object shape, contact/slip events, and forces of contacted objects. It will uniquely fuse visual and tactile information for object handling and pose estimation resulting in flexible robotic system that handles objects more like humans do. This approach addresses key weaknesses in vision-based robotic manufacturing, such as occlusion and dislodging when parts are grasped. Current industrial robots are restricted in their ability to handle small, irregularly shaped, soft, or fragile parts. Existing solutions rely on expensive and complex 3D-vision systems or repetitive manual labor. This solution is two-fold: (1) A new flexible tactile sensor that can be tailored to a wide variety of form factors; (2) Software to fuse the tactile data with a vision system to estimate pose of objects in pick-and-place tasks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Perception Robotics has developed a gripper with novel tactile sensing technology. The gripper addresses the need for a low cost, “sensing” molded gripper sensor that provides force and temperature feedback. The outcome will allow robots to collaborate with an integrated sense of touch to handle small, soft, delicate or irregularly shaped objects. There is a current gap for a product that is able to handle soft and delicate objects without combining the added complexity and cost of a vision system. The technology created by Perception Robotics is a molded silicone structure with integrated sensor that allows for force and temperature feedback. The “fingers” or tactile sensors provide compliance, force and bump detection and contains a thermal sensor for temperature sensitive applications. The technology was also developed in two versions where one could be used for sensitive applications and the other for more robust tasks. The thermal sensors also allow for temperature feedback to be utilized in temperature sensitive applications. This technology advances the field of robotics and sensors by bringing it one step closer to replicating a “human” response in end-of-arm tooling products. This is a transformative step towards greatly increasing the field of operation and scope, allowing for the technology to be applied in other industries such as healthcare and service and hospitality. The possibilities and applications are numerous and the introduction into the robotics industry will be the stepping stone for expansion into varied fields of application.

The tactile gripper can be marketed towards the materials handling industry and typical pick and place applications such as assembly, bin picking, packaging and inspection. Furthermore, the robotics industry is set to disrupt traditional industries like food handling and preparation, agriculture and farming. This global industry market is expected to grow at a compounded annual growth rate of 5% and reach $175 billion by 2020, with robotics drastically improving the return on investment (ROI) and overall efficiency. With such expected growth, the Perception Robotics Tactile Gripper will be well suited to serve a multitude of applications. Furthermore, the reduction in cost will enable healthy competition with existing products in the market whilst facilitating the efficiency of any business and reducing the risk of repetitive and over-exertion injuries for employees. The benefit to society can be measured by (ROI) on businesses with potential to lower cost and increase profit margins, as well as delivering overall lower cost product to the customer as a benefit of reduced operational cost. The introduction of this technology into specific industries such as agriculture, farming and food handling will allow for reduced overall cost, and with further development, open the doors to creating affordable products and solutions in these marketplaces, benefiting societal development as a whole.

Currently the product has been showcased in international and local trade shows with plans for product release following testing and qualification.   In June 2018 Perception Robotics, merged with two other end of arm tooling companies and adopted the OnRobot brand, henceforth becoming OnRobot Los Angeles. The products referred to in this report are a product of Perception Robotics as a result of this NSF grant. The merger will pave the way for this technology to be released into the market as a specific product. The plan for release is supported by the resources gained in the merger, with international sales teams, marketing tools, testing and verification all being planned and executed by OnRobot A/S. The path for a successful product release follows that of other similar products developed by OnRobot A/S that are currently in the market today. This product development cycle is supported by an international team of extremely qualified engineers, sales, marketing and business personnel being led by an industry leader in the field of robotics.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

    Tactile Gripper
